fact: The Earth's global average temperature has increased by around 1.1°C since the pre-industrial era, primarily due to human activities.
Recycling one aluminum can saves enough energy to run a TV for three hours.
Around 8 million tons of plastic waste escapes into the oceans every year, which is equivalent to setting five garbage bags full of trash on every foot of coastline around the world.
The Amazon rainforest produces about 20% of Earth's oxygen and absorbs around 2.2 billion tons of carbon dioxide each year.
A single tree can absorb around 22 kilograms of carbon dioxide per year and release enough oxygen for four people to breathe.
The Great Pacific Garbage Patch, a collection of marine debris in the North Pacific Ocean, is estimated to be twice the size of Texas.
The average American produces about 4.4 pounds (2 kilograms) of trash every day.
Electric cars produce zero direct emissions, which can help improve air quality in cities.
It takes about 450 years for a plastic bottle to decompose in a landfill.
Switching to LED bulbs can reduce energy consumption by up to 80% compared to traditional incandescent bulbs.
Using public transportation instead of a car can reduce your carbon footprint by up to 45%.
Deforestation contributes to about 11% of global greenhouse gas emissions.
Coral reefs support approximately 25% of all marine species.
Producing one pound of beef requires about 1,800 gallons of water.
Air pollution is responsible for about 1 in 8 deaths globally.
Producing recycled paper uses 70% less energy than producing new paper from raw materials.
Composting food waste helps reduce methane emissions from landfills.
Global wildlife populations have declined by an average of 69% since 1970.
Green buildings can reduce energy consumption by up to 30%.
The ozone layer is healing, thanks to global bans on ozone-depleting substances.
Turning off the tap while brushing your teeth can save 8 gallons of water per day.
One reusable bag can eliminate hundreds of plastic bags over its lifetime.
Solar energy is the most abundant energy resource on Earth.
Wetlands can store 3–5 times more carbon than tropical forests.
An estimated 33% of all food produced globally is wasted.
